A celebration of the careers of three Melbourne High School employees was recently held in the high school cafeteria. Those retiring are Melody Carroll, Laura Sipe, and Lanelle Love. Mrs. Carroll leaves the district with 24 years of dedicated service as does Mrs. Sipe, who has spent her entire career of 27 years with Melbourne School District. Mrs. Love, who worked tirelessly in the cafeteria, has been employed since 2015. Mr. Jim Carroll, MHS principal, presented the ladies with custom-made cutting boards with their names and years of service engraved upon them. Once Mrs. Carroll, Mrs. Sipe, and Mrs. Love finished sharing their memories and sentiments of Melbourne High as well as their excitement for the future, attendees enjoyed cake and other snacks. Melbourne High will miss these wonderful ladies and their commitment to our students.

Before the Covid-19 outbreak, students in Meghan Warner's Pre-AP Geometry class were assigned to build "water towers". The projects were due the week school was dismissed for the outbreak.

The instructions were to model the water tower after an existing water tower, calculate the volume of water the tower could hold, and compare it to an existing water tower. Students would also have received extra credit if the model they built could hold water as well.

Student Weston Edwards had successfully completed his project ahead of time.Using the conversion factor of 7.48 gallons per cubic foot, the real water tower holds around 281,500 gallons, and Weston's model water tower holds about 2.75 gallons and does not leak!

Congratulations, Weston, on a job well done!

As always, Melbourne School District strives to make the best decision in accordance to the health and well-being of our students and community. We will continue monitoring the situation with the Arkansas Department of Health and the Arkansas Department of Education and will keep you informed as the situation develops.

Melbourne High School has awarded the first ever MHS Teacher of the Month to Mrs. Joanna Fulbright!

This is an award that is voted on by peers and administration. The criteria is as follows:
A teacher who:
displays grit without ego,
serves and inspires,
seeks perpetual growth,
spreads joy & optimism,
goes above & beyond to help others,
has an outstanding team attitude,
works outside the "TO DO" list,
and thirsts for constant improvement!

Winners of this award will receive a framed certificate to keep and hang in their classroom, a sign for their classroom door that says, "Teacher of the Month", a trophy to display in their classroom for the month of their reign, one class period of their choosing when administration will watch their classes, and one free lunch meal from Bailey's Country Cooking.

Melbourne High School
December 9, 2019 at 3:32 PM ·

Economics, art, and holiday traditions combined to create a unique opportunity for MHS artists. Under the direction of teacher Katelyn Battles, members of the Melbourne High School Art Club created ornaments for the 2019 Christmas tree display at the Arkansas Governor’s Mansion. Students researched holiday traditions of Sweden, one of the top countries with economic investments in Arkansas, to design and create their ornaments. MHS was one of 24 Arkansas schools who contributed original art works to celebrate “Christmas Around the World”.

On Sunday, December 8th, students toured the Governor’s Mansion to see their work in place as part of the mansion’s global holiday display and received the appreciation of Governor Asa Hutchinson and First Lady Susan Hutchinson. The First Lady talked with students extensively, discussing artistic style and Arkansas economics, and encouraging students to be active in their communities and in the arts.
